CatDescriptText: Mrs. Alma Taylor, Wilkinsburg and Mr. Edward Furio, retired, Monessen, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, August 19, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "what action, if any, should be taken and by whom, when Negro members of integrated teams refuse to play before segregated crowds?"  Mrs. Taylor's answer reads: "I don't think anyone should try to force men to play if they don't want to.  It helps break up this segregation when they make a stand against it."  Mr. Furio's answer reads: "It's up to the team to make certain that everyone is treated fairly.  All should have the same advantages, especially in sports.  No one should make it uncomfortable for the colored players.  They are entitled to make an honest living like everyone else."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Alma Taylor wearing dark shirt dress, standing in front of ribbed metal wall; Portrait of Edward Furio wearing light colored striped shirt and eyeglasses, standing in front of store window
